text: I still followed her. Not out of bravado, and not out of heroism—just because I couldn’t stand the idea of her doing everything alone, while I stayed behind pretending everything was fine.
The night snow was thin, but the footprints were clear. She moved too fast, as if slowing down for even a second would make her miss some fixed point in time.
By the time I reached the northern district, she was gone. All I could see was a half-open iron door, gently swaying in the wind.
Behind the door was a staircase leading downward. Cold air surged up from below, as if someone had lit a blue lamp underground.
I didn’t go too far down. I stopped where I could still see—no charging in, no getting in the way, just watching. Because she had said it herself: I would be a hindrance.
From below came soft footsteps, then the sound of metal brushing against stone. Someone was laughing—not a happy laugh, but the kind that said, ‘I’ve finally been waiting for you.’
Alicia stepped out of the shadows. Her cloak dragged across the ground, without a single wasted movement.

Her gaze settled on the center of the sigil array. Someone stood there—thicker black robes, a deeper ring-shaped mark on his chest, as if branded into flesh. A necklace hung at his neck, flashing cold light.
“You finally came.” The black-robed leader looked up, his voice carrying a nauseating certainty. “You come every single time.”
“Enough talk.”
Her voice was flat—so flat it felt like she had pressed every emotion into the hilt of her sword.
“You want the necklace? Can you really take it?”
He raised his hand. The sigils flared for a moment, and the air tightened like it was being twisted. My ears rang, and I nearly lost my footing.
But Alicia didn’t even frown. She simply stepped forward half a pace—as if stepping into a rhythm she already knew by heart.
“I’ve seen this trick before.”
The next second, swordlight flashed like a cold line pulled straight from her hand. Not a slash, not a flourish, but a clean, almost cruelly direct strike.
The black-robed leader’s talisman shattered first. The sigil array crackled sharply as it collapsed. He instinctively retreated—but she already knew where he would go.
“You—!”
He raised his arm to block, but his wrist lost strength as if cut by an invisible thread. The necklace swayed, its silver light flickering against his throat.
Alicia reached out—not to kill him, but to take.
“Give it to me.”
The moment her fingers hooked the necklace, I saw something flash in her eyes—extremely brief, almost like pain.
Then—she pulled.
The sound of the chain snapping was very soft. But that softness felt like something fate itself had been torn apart.
The black-robed leader staggered back. The sigils went dark all at once. He tried to say something, but only breathed out a mouthful of ash-scented air.
Alicia didn’t pursue him. She simply clenched the necklace, as if confirming it was truly in her hand.
“I finally got it.”
There was no sense of victory in her voice—only the exhaustion of someone who could finally move on to the next step.
I should have backed away, but my feet felt nailed to the steps. She suddenly looked up, her gaze landing precisely where I was hiding.
“Come out.”
My throat was dry. “...I didn’t mean to get in the way.”
“You already did.”
She said it bluntly, but the next line sounded more like suppressed anger:
“But you’re still alive—consider yourself lucky.”
She walked up to me, her cloak brushing snow from the steps. She tucked the necklace inside her clothes, pressing a hand to her chest as if afraid it might disappear.
“Back to the inn.”
“And them… that’s it?”
“They won’t pursue us tonight.”
She paused, as if rapidly running through every possibility in her head, then added something more practical:
“Tomorrow, I’ll clean up whatever’s left.”
When we left the underground, the snow had grown heavier. She walked ahead, I followed behind. Neither of us spoke.
Only when the inn’s lights appeared through the fog did she seem to finally let out a breath.
The door closed, shutting the wind outside. The fireplace glow lit her face, but she still didn’t seem warmed.
“Don’t ask me for details.”
“Just remember this—I got what I needed.”
She turned and went upstairs. Her steps were light, but every one of them felt like she was racing against time.
“And—next time, don’t follow.”
I said quietly, “Then next time, don’t go alone.”
She stopped halfway up the stairs, without turning back.
“I’ll try.”
